com.google.cloud.pubsub

Class Subscription

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.google.cloud.pubsub.SubscriptionInfo
      • com.google.cloud.pubsub.Subscription
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Serializable

    public class Subscription
extends SubscriptionInfo
    A Google Cloud Pub/Sub subscription. A subscription represents the stream of messages from a single, specific topic, to be delivered to the subscribing application. Pub/Sub subscriptions support both push and pull message delivery.

    In a push subscription, the Pub/Sub server sends a request to the subscriber application, at a preconfigured endpoint (see PushConfig). The subscriber's HTTP response serves as an implicit acknowledgement: a success response indicates that the message has been succesfully processed and the Pub/Sub system can delete it from the subscription; a non-success response indicates that the Pub/Sub server should resend it (implicit "nack").

    In a pull subscription, the subscribing application must explicitly pull messages using one of PubSub.pull(String, int), PubSub.pullAsync(String, int) or PubSub.pullAsync(String, PubSub.MessageProcessor callback, PubSub.PullOption...). When messages are pulled with PubSub.pull(String, int) or PubSub.pullAsync(String, int) the subscribing application must also explicitly acknowledge them using one of PubSub.ack(String, Iterable), PubSub.ack(String, String, String...), PubSub.ackAsync(String, Iterable) or PubSub.ackAsync(String, String, String...).

    Subscription adds a layer of service-related functionality over SubscriptionInfo. Objects of this class are immutable. To get a Subscription object with the most recent information use reload() or reloadAsync().

    See Also:
    Pub/Sub Data Model, Subscriber Guide, Serialized Form

      • delete

        public boolean delete()
        Deletes this subscription.

        Example of deleting the subscription. 

         
 boolean deleted = subscription.delete();
 if (deleted) {
   // the subscription was deleted
 } else {
   // the subscription was not found
 }
        Returns:
        true if the subscription was deleted, false if it was not found
        Throws:
        PubSubException - upon failure

      • deleteAsync

        public Future<Boolean> deleteAsync()
        Sends a request for deleting this subscription. This method returns a Future object to consume the result. Future.get() returns true if the subscription was deleted, false if it was not found.

        Example of asynchronously deleting the subscription. 

         
 Future<Boolean> future = subscription.deleteAsync();
 // ...
 boolean deleted = future.get();
 if (deleted) {
   // the subscription was deleted
 } else {
   // the subscription was not found
 }

      • reload

        public Subscription reload()
        Fetches current subscription's latest information. Returns null if the subscription does not exist.

        Example of getting the subscription's latest information. 

         
 Subscription latestSubscription = subscription.reload();
 if (latestSubscription == null) {
   // the subscription was not found
 }
        Returns:
        a Subscription object with latest information or null if not found
        Throws:
        PubSubException - upon failure

      • reloadAsync

        public Future<Subscription> reloadAsync()
        Sends a request for fetching current subscription's latest information. This method returns a Future object to consume the result. Future.get() returns the requested subscription or null if not found.

        Example of asynchronously getting the subscription's latest information. 

         
 Future<Subscription> future = subscription.reloadAsync();
 // ...
 Subscription latestSubscription = future.get();
 if (latestSubscription == null) {
   // the subscription was not found
 }
        Returns:
        a Subscription object with latest information or null if not found
        Throws:
        PubSubException - upon failure

      • replacePushConfig

        public void replacePushConfig(PushConfig pushConfig)
        Sets the push configuration for this subscription. This may be used to change a push subscription to a pull one (passing a null pushConfig parameter) or vice versa. This methods can also be used to change the endpoint URL and other attributes of a push subscription. Messages will accumulate for delivery regardless of changes to the push configuration.

        Example of replacing the push configuration of the subscription, setting the push endpoint. 

         
 String endpoint = "https://www.example.com/push";
 PushConfig pushConfig = PushConfig.of(endpoint);
 subscription.replacePushConfig(pushConfig);

        Example of replacing the push configuration of the subscription, making it a pull subscription. 

         
 subscription.replacePushConfig(null);
        Parameters:
        pushConfig - the new push configuration. Use null to unset it
        Throws:
        PubSubException - upon failure, or if the subscription does not exist

      • replacePushConfigAsync

        public Future<Void> replacePushConfigAsync(PushConfig pushConfig)
        Sends a request for updating the push configuration for a specified subscription. This may be used to change a push subscription to a pull one (passing a null pushConfig parameter) or vice versa. This methods can also be used to change the endpoint URL and other attributes of a push subscription. Messages will accumulate for delivery regardless of changes to the push configuration. The method returns a Future object that can be used to wait for the replace operation to be completed.

        Example of asynchronously replacing the push configuration of the subscription, setting the push endpoint. 

         
 String endpoint = "https://www.example.com/push";
 PushConfig pushConfig = PushConfig.of(endpoint);
 Future<Void> future = subscription.replacePushConfigAsync(pushConfig);
 // ...
 future.get();

        Example of asynchronously replacing the push configuration of the subscription, making it a pull subscription. 

         
 Future<Void> future = subscription.replacePushConfigAsync(null);
 // ...
 future.get();
        Parameters:
        pushConfig - the new push configuration. Use null to unset it
        Returns:
        a Future to wait for the replace operation to be completed.

      • pull

        public Iterator<ReceivedMessage> pull(int maxMessages)
        Pulls messages from this subscription. This method possibly returns no messages if no message was available at the time the request was processed by the Pub/Sub service (i.e. the system is not allowed to wait until at least one message is available). Pulled messages have their acknowledge deadline automatically renewed until they are explicitly consumed using Iterator.next().

        Example of pulling a maximum number of messages from the subscription. 

         
 Iterator<ReceivedMessage> messages = subscription.pull(100);
 // Ack deadline is renewed until the message is consumed
 while (messages.hasNext()) {
   ReceivedMessage message = messages.next();
   // do something with message and ack/nack it
   message.ack(); // or message.nack()
 }
        Parameters:
        maxMessages - the maximum number of messages pulled by this method. This method can possibly return fewer messages.
        Throws:
        PubSubException - upon failure

      • pullAsync

        public Future<Iterator<ReceivedMessage>> pullAsync(int maxMessages)
        Sends a request for pulling messages from this subscription. This method returns a Future object to consume the result. Future.get() returns a message iterator. This method possibly returns no messages if no message was available at the time the request was processed by the Pub/Sub service (i.e. the system is not allowed to wait until at least one message is available).

        Example of asynchronously pulling a maximum number of messages from the subscription. 

         
 Future<Iterator<ReceivedMessage>> future = subscription.pullAsync(100);
 // ...
 Iterator<ReceivedMessage> messages = future.get();
 // Ack deadline is renewed until the message is consumed
 while (messages.hasNext()) {
   ReceivedMessage message = messages.next();
   // do something with message and ack/nack it
   message.ack(); // or message.nack()
 }
        Parameters:
        maxMessages - the maximum number of messages pulled by this method. This method can possibly return fewer messages.
        Throws:
        PubSubException - upon failure

      • pullAsync

        public PubSub.MessageConsumer pullAsync(PubSub.MessageProcessor callback,
                                        PubSub.PullOption... options)
        Creates a message consumer that pulls messages from this subscription. You can stop pulling messages by calling PubSub.MessageConsumer.close(). The returned message consumer executes PubSub.MessageProcessor.process(Message) on each pulled message. If PubSub.MessageProcessor.process(Message) executes correctly, the message is acknowledged. If PubSub.MessageProcessor.process(Message) throws an exception, the message is "nacked". For all pulled messages, the ack deadline is automatically renewed until the message is either acknowledged or "nacked".

        The PubSub.PullOption.maxQueuedCallbacks(int) option can be used to control the maximum number of queued messages (messages either being processed or waiting to be processed). The PubSub.PullOption.executorFactory(GrpcServiceOptions.ExecutorFactory) can be used to provide an executor to run message processor callbacks.

        Example of continuously pulling messages from the subscription. 

         
 String subscriptionName = "my_subscription_name";
 MessageProcessor callback = new MessageProcessor() {
   public void process(Message message) throws Exception {
     // Ack deadline is renewed until this method returns
     // Message is acked if this method returns successfully
     // Message is nacked if this method throws an exception
   }
 };
 MessageConsumer consumer = subscription.pullAsync(callback);
 // ...
 // Stop pulling
 consumer.close();
        Parameters:
        callback - the callback to be executed on each message
        options - pulling options
        Returns:
        a message consumer for the provided subscription and options

      • getPolicy

        public Policy getPolicy()
        Returns the IAM access control policy for this subscription. Returns null if the subscription was not found.

        Example of getting the subscription's policy. 

         
 Policy policy = subscription.getPolicy();
 if (policy == null) {
   // subscription was not found
 }
        Throws:
        PubSubException - upon failure

      • getPolicyAsync

        public Future<Policy> getPolicyAsync()
        Sends a request for getting the IAM access control policy for this subscription. This method returns a Future object to consume the result. Future.get() returns the requested policy or null if the subscription was not found.

        Example of asynchronously getting the subscription's policy. 

         
 Future<Policy> future = subscription.getPolicyAsync();
 // ...
 Policy policy = future.get();
 if (policy == null) {
   // subscription was not found
 }
        Throws:
        PubSubException - upon failure

      • replacePolicy

        public Policy replacePolicy(Policy newPolicy)
        Sets the IAM access control policy for this subscription. Replaces any existing policy. This method returns the new policy.

        It is recommended that you use the read-modify-write pattern. This pattern entails reading the project's current policy, updating it locally, and then sending the modified policy for writing. Cloud IAM solves the problem of conflicting processes simultaneously attempting to modify a policy by using the etag property. This property is used to verify whether the policy has changed since the last request. When you make a request with an etag value, the value in the request is compared with the existing etag value associated with the policy. The policy is written only if the etag values match. If the etags don't match, a PubSubException is thrown, denoting that the server aborted update. If an etag is not provided, the policy is overwritten blindly.

        Example of replacing the subscription's policy. 

         
 Policy policy = subscription.getPolicy();
 Policy updatedPolicy = policy.toBuilder()
     .addIdentity(Role.viewer(), Identity.allAuthenticatedUsers())
     .build();
 updatedPolicy = subscription.replacePolicy(updatedPolicy);
        Throws:
        PubSubException - upon failure

      • replacePolicyAsync

        public Future<Policy> replacePolicyAsync(Policy newPolicy)
        Sends a request to set the IAM access control policy for this subscription. Replaces any existing policy. This method returns a Future object to consume the result. Future.get() returns the new policy.

        It is recommended that you use the read-modify-write pattern. This pattern entails reading the project's current policy, updating it locally, and then sending the modified policy for writing. Cloud IAM solves the problem of conflicting processes simultaneously attempting to modify a policy by using the etag property. This property is used to verify whether the policy has changed since the last request. When you make a request with an etag value, the value in the request is compared with the existing etag value associated with the policy. The policy is written only if the etag values match. If the etags don't match, Future.get() will throw a ExecutionException caused by a PubSubException, denoting that the server aborted update. If an etag is not provided, the policy is overwritten blindly.

        Example of asynchronously replacing the subscription's policy. 

         
 Policy policy = subscription.getPolicy();
 Policy updatedPolicy = policy.toBuilder()
     .addIdentity(Role.viewer(), Identity.allAuthenticatedUsers())
     .build();
 Future<Policy> future = subscription.replacePolicyAsync(updatedPolicy);
 // ...
 updatedPolicy = future.get();
        Throws:
        PubSubException - upon failure

      • testPermissions

        public List<Boolean> testPermissions(List<String> permissions)
        Returns the permissions that a caller has on this subscription. You typically don't call this method if you're using Google Cloud Platform directly to manage permissions. This method is intended for integration with your proprietary software, such as a customized graphical user interface. For example, the Cloud Platform Console tests IAM permissions internally to determine which UI should be available to the logged-in user.

        Example of testing whether the caller has the provided permissions on the subscription. 

         
 List<String> permissions = new LinkedList<>();
 permissions.add("pubsub.subscriptions.get");
 List<Boolean> testedPermissions = subscription.testPermissions(permissions);
        Returns:
        A list of booleans representing whether the caller has the permissions specified (in the order of the given permissions)
        Throws:
        PubSubException - upon failure
        See Also:
        Permissions and Roles

      • testPermissionsAsync

        public Future<List<Boolean>> testPermissionsAsync(List<String> permissions)
        Sends a request to get the permissions that a caller has on this subscription.

        You typically don't call this method if you're using Google Cloud Platform directly to manage permissions. This method is intended for integration with your proprietary software, such as a customized graphical user interface. For example, the Cloud Platform Console tests IAM permissions internally to determine which UI should be available to the logged-in user.

        Example of asynchronously testing whether the caller has the provided permissions on the subscription. 

         
 List<String> permissions = new LinkedList<>();
 permissions.add("pubsub.subscriptions.get");
 Future<List<Boolean>> future = subscription.testPermissionsAsync(permissions);
 // ...
 List<Boolean> testedPermissions = future.get();
        Returns:
        A Future object to consume the result. Future.get() returns a list of booleans representing whether the caller has the permissions specified (in the order of the given permissions)
        Throws:
        PubSubException - upon failure
        See Also:
        Permissions and Roles
